block.p: BELMONT 6 Brothers With Chisels And the Art They Made

Attilio Piccirilli (pronounced pee-che-REE-lee) and his five brothers, all sculptors, operated a studio at 467 East 142nd Street in the Bronx from 1890 to 1945. Executing the designs of more celebrated sculptors, the brothers were responsible for many statues and monuments throughout New York, including the Four Continents in front of the United States Custom House (1907) and the lions of the New York Public Library (1911). Their work also includes the figure inside the Lincoln Memorial in Washington.
BELMONT 6 Brothers With Chisels And the Art They Made

Attilio Piccirilli (pronounced pee-che-REE-lee) and his five brothers, all sculptors, operated a studio at 467 East 142nd Street in the Bronx from 1890 to 1945. Executing the designs of more celebrated sculptors, the brothers were responsible for many statues and monuments throughout New York, including the Four Continents in front of the United States Custom House (1907) and the lions of the New York Public Library (1911). Their work also includes the figure inside the Lincoln Memorial in Washington.

The Belmont Regional Library and the Enrico Fermi Cultural Committee are presenting ''A Salute to the Piccirilli Brothers,'' who also produced many works of their own design. In addition to a visual exhibit, a slide presentation on the life and work of the family will be narrated by Bill Carroll, a teacher and amateur sculptor, and Mary Shelley.
''A Salute to the Piccirilli Brothers,'' Thursday 7:30 p.m.; Belmont Regional Branch Library, 610 East 186th Street, at Hughes Avenue, the Bronx; free; (718) 933-6410.
ST. GEORGE The People of Staten Island Well Before Columbus

When the first humans arrived on Staten Island more than 12,000 years ago, they encountered a bleak, tundralike landscape and a cold climate. The lives of these settlers are explored in an exhibit at the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, titled ''The Lenape: The First Staten Islanders.'' (At left, a stone head that was found in the Concord section in 1884.)

In addition to specimens like these, an assortment of local Indian artifacts will help illustrate the lives of the Lenape people, including an array of stone tools like projectile points (arrowheads), grooved axes, mortars, pestles, hammer stones and reconstructed clay pots.
The exhibit will also examine archaeological methods, specifically how the past is recreated and understood from the scraps of what remains.

''The Lenape: The First Staten Islanders''; through Dec. 31, open 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Monday through Saturday, 1 to 5 p.m. Sunday; Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences, 75 Stuyvesant Place, near Wall Street; suggested donation $2.50 adults, $1.50 students and people 62 or older; (718) 727-1135.
RIVERDALE New Judaica At Home for the Aged

Three new exhibits have opened at the Judaica Museum at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale. ''Collectors' Vision'' examines such topics as the definition of Judaica, the reasons behind collectors' choices, and fakes. The exhibit includes an extensive collection of objects from the Bezalel School of Art in Jerusalem and other relics, such as a miniature Torah ark of painted wood (pictured at right).

The exhibition ''Threads of Holiness: Synagogue and Home Textiles'' includes textiles from the museum's collection, including a matzo holder decorated with fish scales and sequins from the 19th century.
The exhibition ''Twentieth Century Pop: Pop-up and Holiday Cards From the Steinberger Judaica Collection'' features greeting cards from 1915 to 1950.

Judaica Museum; through Dec. 28, Monday through Thursday 1 to 4:30 p.m. and Sunday, 1 to 5 p.m.; Hebrew Home for the Aged, 5901 Palisade Avenue at 261st Street, Riverdale, the Bronx; free; (718) 581-1787.
